captions.text:
In the Northeast Pacific Ocean seafloor cameras
stream live video to the internet. From half

a world away a young citizen scientist witnessed
an event never before seen on camera.

When we first got alerted to this video by
a young man named Kirill from the Ukraine,

14 years of age, we immediately went to the
literature and to our colleagues who know

more about mammals to find out roughly what
kind of dives and depths are out there.

It turns out that the range that was reported
were between 400 to 4000 metres, a full order

of magnitude. And it was not nailed down very
well. Now we have, through the help of this

young man, a video showing how deep a female
northern elephant seal goes to and what it's
doing down there.

So here we have the ruler being laid down
in front of the pod, the pod has a camera

on it that goes on periodically, in this case
it's been going on for 15 minutes every two
hours or so.

We basically have a ruler here to understand
the size of the animals we are seeing. So

this is the footage that Kirill captured.
It shows a hagfish meandering along the seafloor

and now near the top of the frame you'll see
the entry of the female northern elephant
seal.

This is the first picture we've ever seen
of any kind of predation by a deep diving

seal like this and we can use this to understand
how they eat their food at that depth, what

kind of food they're eating at that depth
and how they find it.

In this case, likely because there was a bright
light shining on it.

This is a very valuable addition to science
and we have reams and reams of this video

data that we could try to mine using data
mining techniques but the best miners we know

out there are people like you, the citizen
scientists.

comments.text:
It could have been spat back out though, we really don't see what happens 
after. In most videos of the haggish using this defense he's always at 
least half eaten, the video cuts off too soon to tell..﻿
comments.author: iconsumeinfants

comments.text:
That's pretty amazing, especially since that's the first time I've seen 
anything successfully eat hagfish.
comments.author: Will Holz

comments.text:
உக்ரைனைச் சேர்ந்த கிரில் டுட்கோ எனப்படும் 14 வயதுச் சிறுவன் ஆழ்கடலில் 
நடைபெறும் அரிய, நிகழ்வுகளை படம்பீடித்து வீடியோ மற்றும் புகைப்பட 
கிளிப்புக்களை மேற்கொள்ளும் ஆர்வமுடையவன்.

இச்சிறுவன் சமீபத்தில் 2933 அடி ஆழத்தில் கடலுக்கடியில் எடுத்த அரிய 
வீடியோவைக் கனடாவின் விஞ்ஞானிகளுக்கு அனுப்பிப் பெரும் புகழைப் பெற்றுள்ளான்.

இந்த வீடியோவில் 2933 ஆழத்தில் கனடாவின் பசுபிக் கடற்கரைக்கு அண்மித்த Barkley 
Canyon கடல் மேற்பரப்பில் ஒரு யானை சீல் (Elephant seal) ஹக்ஃபிஷ் (hagfish) 
எனப்படும் சிறிய மீன் ஒன்றைக் கவ்வும் காட்சி இடம்பெற்றுள்ளது. இது குறித்து 
கனேடிய ஆழ்கடல் உயிரியல் விஞ்ஞானி ஸ்டீவன் மிஹாலி இன்னொரு வீடியோவில் 
விளக்கமளித்துள்ளார். டுட்கோ எனும் இச்சிறுவன் கடல் தரையில் இது போன்ற பல 
வீடியோக்களை எடுத்து தனது யூடியூப் சேனலில் பதிவேற்றம் செய்து வருகின்றான். 
இவனுக்கும் ஆழ்கடல் உயிரியலில் அலாதிப் பிரியம்.

மிக அரிய வகை உயிரினமான யானை சீல் அல்லது Elephant seal எனும் இந்தப் பாலூட்டி 
இவ்வீடியோவிலும் முழுமையாகத் தென்படவில்லை. எனினும் அதன் மூக்கு மற்றும் மீசை 
காரணமாக அது யானை சீல் என இனங்காணப் பட்டுள்ளது. மேலும் இப்பாலூட்டி மிக ஆழமான 
சமுத்திரங்களில் 5000 அடி ஆழம் வரை செல்லக் கூடியன எனவும் இரண்டு 
மணித்தியாலங்களுக்கு அங்கு தங்கியிருக்க வல்லன என்றும் கூறப்படுகின்றது.

 விஞ்ஞானிகள் இவ்வீடியோ தொடர்பில் கொடுக்கும் விளக்கம்::-﻿
comments.author: GNANAMOORTHY PONNAIER

comments.text:
Hello, Ilya. Elephant seals are pretty amazing. Unlike other seals elephant 
seals spend 90% of their time underwater, surfacing only to breathe. They 
can hold their breath over 100 minutes and dive to depths greater than 1500 
metres. Water pressure at such depths exceeds 170 atmospheres or over 
17,500 kilopascals (2500 pounds per square inch)! Our Pod 4 platform in 
Barkley Canyon is positioned at a depth of 894 m—nearly 3 times the world 
record scuba diving depth of 318 m.
comments.author: Neptune Canada

comments.text: Believe me, this is not the last thing that he can do
comments.author: Ilya Dudko

comments.text:
should ask about the conditions for such a dive seal? Water pressure at 
depth, water temperature? What allowing the mammal to avoid decompression 
sickness? which substances of blood allow the diving seal at great depth? 
What are the processes of the nerve at a depth? Many questions and few 
answers ...
comments.author: Ilya Dudko

Very interesting .The announcer said the seal was able to see the Hagfish 
because of the lights. The elephant seal still goes down there without

that depth in total darkness without lights.

It's a big deal because we've never recorded it on camera before. Data 
recorders have tracked diving times and depths, but we've never actually 
seen an elephant seal at the bottom feeding.

comments.text:
Oh, Come on! Anyone can see that was Wilford Brimley! Or perhaps Mike 
Holmgren? Wait, after seeing the second, narrated version, I'm thinking 
that perhaps ocean scientists know no depths to which they wouldn't sink 
(quite literally) in order to drum up some U-Toob views! So tell us, Dr. 
Mihaly... how does 'slime eel' taste? Chicken? But seriously, great video, 
and thanks for sharing it with us 'land blubbers' in the 'South 48'. ;~)
comments.author: Boo Yahu

comments.text: There are crabs in that video.
comments.author: oceannetworks canada

comments.text:
If you're interested in sea spiders, we have a cool video of sea spiders on 
our channel. Look for the video called "Striding Sea Spider"
comments.author: oceannetworks canada

comments.text:
We have thousands of hours of underwater video taken by remotely-operated 
vehicles. We also have multiple thousands of hours of video taken on 
automated schedules by our seafloor video cameras. Way more than the staff 
here could hope to look through, which is why we invite the world to watch 
and find interesting things nobody else has ever seen.
comments.author: oceannetworks canada
